user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of get_rq_uname_type:
```c
_MHD_static_inline enum MHD_DigestAuthUsernameType
get_rq_uname_type (const struct MHD_RqDAuth *params)
{
  if (NULL != params->username.value.str)
  {
    if (NULL == params->username_ext.value.str)
      return params->userhash ?
             MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_USERHASH :
             MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_STANDARD;
    else  /* Both 'username' and 'username*' are used */
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_INVALID;
  }
  else if (NULL != params->username_ext.value.str)
  {
    if (! params->username_ext.quoted && ! params->userhash &&
        (MHD_DAUTH_EXT_PARAM_MIN_LEN <= params->username_ext.value.len) )
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_EXTENDED;
    else
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_INVALID;
  }

  return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_MISSING;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function get_rq_uname_type:
#define MHD_DAUTH_EXT_PARAM_MIN_LEN MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_(MHD_DAUTH_EXT_PARAM_PREFIX"'")
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I examined all controlling expressions in get_rq_uname_type:
- if (NULL != params->username.value.str)
- if (NULL == params->username_ext.value.str)
- else if (NULL != params->username_ext.value.str)
- if (! params->username_ext.quoted && ! params->userhash && (MHD_DAUTH_EXT_PARAM_MIN_LEN <= params->username_ext.value.len) )

None of these are invariant constant expressions: each depends on members of the runtime parameter object params (pointer values, boolean flags, or a length field). The macro MHD_DAUTH_EXT_PARAM_MIN_LEN expands to a compile-time integer, but it is compared to params->username_ext.value.len (a runtime value), so the combined controlling expression is not an invariant. There are no do-while or while constructs with constant controlling expressions, nor any literal constant conditions such as if (1) or if (0). Therefore no controlling expressions in this function trigger MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 and no fragments need further investigation.
